posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked:
today and on saturday we have had 2 krakenx60s die, both were attached to an SDSMK4i swerve drive as the drive motor, there was no clear damage to the wires or wiring. the failure mode we saw in both cases was the motor would lock and squeel with a loud coil whine, the first one since it died now no longer whines, but has the hardware fault status light and status in tuner x. here are a few things we have tried to check so far.

wire run was clean and undamaged

wires near the bolts/crimps to the kraken were undamaged and properly torqued

frame did not have power going through it

PDH Port was different between the 2 motors(ig both could be bad, but we plugged a falcon into one since and that did not fail)

the motor doesnt fail immediately, for the second failed motor we were able to set it up update id/firmware(had not yet tested moving it yet)

the first failed motor worked for over a month

there are no other faults on the motor that now has the hardware fault

the area near the swerve mods motor was not sharp and didnt seem to be touching any of the conductor

if yall have any more idea to test, or ideas about how to prevent this in the next motor let me know, we only have one left and i dont want that to break as well(we are planning on buying more, and possibly some off if other teams nearby)

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked: Check the cooling ports, make sure that there wasn’t anything stuck in too far that would scratch the rotor.

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked: You should probably contact CTRE support

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: main thing about that, i will prolly contact them and send it in for repair, but before we kill our last kraken i need to try and find some explanation for the failure so we can avoid it, so that we arent left without any motors left come competition next week.

posts.name: Drew Whitney
posts.cooked:
Are the screws for the power, can, and cover plate in the correct holes or the correct screws? Using the wrong ones can cause a bound motor and/or damage to your motor controller , as they are all very similar and can be confusing.

On a separate note, we had a drive motor failure on the MK4n (Kraken X60, new for this year) at CALA this past weekend after two years of running Krakens. We could find no cause and are in the process of contacting WCP / CTRE . If you can’t find anything else wrong, I would suggest reaching out to them as well.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: we did check and the wires were attached properly and torqued as well. and the cover was also properly attached. they are the included screws as well

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: do you have any more info on the failure you guys had?

posts.name: Drew Whitney
posts.cooked:
It was completely random. The motor came off the field after our first playoff match working fine with no issues. During our pit check before the next match, we found it was frozen, zero movement from the motor. Unless it failed right at the end of the match, there was no indication of a problem.

When we ran Falcons, we would have a Falcon bind about once per regional and could never find an answer.

I strongly recommend reaching out to WCP / CTRE to see if they have any additional ideas.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
Kadd:

i will prolly contact them and send it in for repair, but before we kill our last kraken i need to try and find some explanation for the failure so we can avoid it

I’d encourage you to work things in parallel. Who do you think is better able to determine why they died, the manufacturer or some random people on an Internet forum?

posts.name: Dalton
posts.cooked:
To echo everyone else, reach out to support@ctr-electronics.com

Do you have your cooling ports protected and you are using the provided terminal covers? Exposed cooling ports can provide a pathway to the motor for things like aluminum debris which can permanently damage the motor.

If you aren’t using the cooling ports, always make sure they are covered.
